title: Amplifying Artifacts with Speech Enhancement in Voice Anti-spoofing
author: Thanapat Trachu (Chulalongkorn University), Thanathai Lertpetchpun (University of Southern California), Ekapol Chuangsuwanich (Chulalongkorn University), ...
relevance_why: The paper presents a method for amplifying artifacts in spoofed audio using speech enhancement techniques, which can inform advancements in Haohe Liu's work on audio quality enhancement and restoration.
background: The task involves detecting whether an audio utterance is genuine or spoofed, with a focus on enhancing the detection of spoofed utterances by amplifying their inherent artifacts.
contribution: This paper introduces a model-agnostic pipeline that enhances spoofed speech artifacts using a three-step process involving noise addition, noise extraction, and noise amplification, achieving significant improvements in detection performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily aimed at refining countermeasures focused on architectural improvements without addressing artifact visibility in spoofed utterances.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by explicitly targeting the amplification of artifacts rather than merely their detection, leading to better classification outcomes.

key_innovation: The pipeline effectively intertwines noise and artifact amplification to enhance the detectability of spoofed audio without losing significant quality from genuine voices.
real_world_impact: This method can significantly bolster the robustness of speaker verification systems against spoofing attacks, enhancing security in various applications such as voice banking and personal assistants.
limitations: The paper does not mention specific limitations but implies potential challenges with the choice of noise types and SNR levels for optimal performance.

new_terms.anti-spoofing: **Anti-spoofing** refers to techniques used to determine whether an audio input is authentic or has been artificially generated or manipulated.
new_terms.signal-to-noise ratio (SNR): **Signal-to-noise ratio (SNR)** is a measure used in communications and signal processing to express the ratio of signal power to noise power, indicating the quality of the transmitted information.
